page.title: 05TOFT HILL HALL FARM(CONT)
page.content: to grow freely until July when it is cut and dried in the sun. This dry grass, hay, is then baled, stacked and eventually led in by a tractor using a bale-grab which can lift 21 bales. These are stored in a barn and used for winter feed. Bales are raised up high by the use of an elevator. Food for the animals is obtained in this way and other supplementary foods such as cowcake are fed. The sheep on the farm consist of 3 breeds. Firstly there are Mules which are a cross between Swaledale and Border Leicester breeds and these are the main breeding ewes of the farm. Secondly there were a few Masham ewes and thirdly there were three Suffolk tups which were used for breeding. There were 112 ewes which in 1985 had produced 180 lambs. The sheep were marked with a green
